description.narrative: Output 1: The GoI Plan for SSR is developed. Output 2: The democratic oversight capacity of the SDC is strengthened. Output 3. GoI engagement with civil society in the field of SSR is increased.

1.1 Indicator: SSR committee has an established platform mechanism and leads SSR discussions for both government and relevant external stakeholders 1.2 Indicator: GoI SSR Plan developed by the SSR Committee through extensive internal and external consultations 1.3 Indicator: SSR Committee has relevant capacity to design and conduct continuous internal assessments and mapping of the Iraq security sector 1.4 Indicator: Close engagement with provinces to build support of GoI SSR efforts and to ensure their inputs are considered within the SSR Plan 2.2 Indicator: SD Committee identifies potential parliaments with whom partnerships could be initiated in order to develop its capacity through peer-to-peer engagement and experience sharing with relevant institutions in other countries. 3.1 Indicator: Better overview of Iraqi civil society actors who could help the GoI in driving forward and advocating for the SSR agenda. 3.5 Indicator: ANCSS institutional and research capacity enhanced Strengthened capacity enables the ANCSS to contribute to policy development on security issues through provision of recommendations to the NSC

comment.narrative: 1.1 Baseline: SSR Committee established but lacking capacity 1.2 Baseline: Absence of existing GoI action plan for reform of the security sector in Iraq 1.3 Baseline: Absence of GoI capacity to conduct baseline assessments and mapping exercises of the Iraqi security sector and its existing capacities 1.4 Baseline:Few or no efforts to advocate for or to inform provincial government structures of activities related to reform of the Iraqi security sector 2.2 Baseline: Little to no engagement with other national parliaments in the field of defence and security. Suitable parliamentary partners have yet to be identified. 3.1 Baseline: Very few if any CSOs who specialise on issues related to SSR have been identified 3.5 Baseline: Al Nahrain Centre for Strategic Studies established but with weak institutional and research capacity . While the National Security Council (NSC) is the ANCSS’s primary client, they have received little to no contribution from the Centre to inform policy development on security issues as a result of limited capacity
2.1 a) Implementation of Road map initiated with the at least 2 out of 6 Road Map Core Police functions fully operational.

During the reporting period UNDP and Danish National Police delivered 4 Mid Level Management Training Courses to a total of 126 Police Officers (118 male and 8 female). The participatns represented a total of 15 liberated and, other provinces - i.e. Ninewa, Sala- al- Din, Anabr, Baghdad, Basra, Kirkuk, Diyala,Wassit, Babil, Karbala, Al Diwaniya, Thi- Qar., Al Muthana, Al Najaf and Missan. Participants ranking ranged from Brigadier, Colonel, Lt. Colonel, Major, Captain, 1st Lieutenant and, to Lieutenant.
The 3 -week long courses were held from 27January -14 Feburary; 17 Feburary -7 March; and, 10 - 28 March, 07-25 April 2019. In addition to Danish Police Instructors 3 Norwegian Instructors were also invovled in the training delivery resulting from a Nordic Police Trainer Agreement between Denmarks National Police and, other Nordic Countries. In March 2019 Danish Ambassador H.E. Gerth Meinecke visited the Mid-Level Management Police Training Course at MoI Training Centre and, also addressed the participants. The course topics were reviewed and, revised following the first course in November 2019 to make them more Iraqi specific informed by MoI TQD and, participant feedback. Course topics include the following: Introdcution ; 5 biggest channges of the Iraqi Police Service; Human Rights; Democratic Policing; Leadership Management; Training, Coacing and Mentoring; Situational Leadership; Communication; Operational Use of IELP; Process of Criminal Investigations; and, Operational Planning. Overall there is a high level of buy-in from MoI TQD for the Mid- Level Management Course. There is also signficant IP interest on the course both in terms of potential in-kind deployment of qualified instructors to support the training delivery and to learn from best practice. The next course is scheduled to take place from 1 -25 April 2019 in Baghdad.
UNDP developed a summary of lessons learned and best pratice from the Mild - Level Police Management courses to-date and, shared with MoI TQD Head Major General Ziad for his persual in order to further improve the course delivery in 2019 and beyond. MoI TQD appreciated UNDP approach to regular appraisal of course delivery and, documentation of best practice and learnings.

4.1SSRP implementation mechanism in place and operational. 4.2 SSRP Higher Committee and Technical/ Support Committee have necessary skills to implement and monitor the SSRP. 4.3 One GoI led awareness -raising campaign initiated to inform the public about governments SSR efforts. 5.1 MoI Road Map Committee has successfully led the Civilian and Local Police Road Map elaboration. 5.2 Civilian and Local Policing Road Map endorsed and operational. 5.3 Improved community trust in security and justice providers and demonstrated through joint collaborations to enhance community safety and local level. 5.4 8-10 training and mentoring sessions on KLP delivered to Iraqi Civilian Police and trainees are using their newly acquired skills in the operational context.
6.1 SDC provides oversight role in the SSRP implementation and improved SDC and civil society collaboration in oversight aspects.
6.2 At least 3 public hearings conducted by SDC with recommendations to improve security sector governance and oversight in joint collaboration with civil society
6.3 SDC and civil society are collaborating succefully to conduct public hearings
6.4 One public perception survey conducted to gauge local safety and security in post ISIL -Iraq.

SSRP implementation mechanism and working methods are in place and SSRP is being implemented through the GoI appointed SSR Support Committee under the overall oversight of GoI appointed High Committee that is charied by the DNSA. SSR Suppoert Committee Meets weekly and coordinates implementaiton at institutional level. During the reporing period all ‘systems’ are operating, including working in progress to estalished the delayed ‘Defence and Internal Security Strategy’ cross-ministerial committee. As a result of UNDP effective International Parter (IP) Coordination efforts for broader SSRP implementation the current International Partner support to the 7 SSRP Systems is as follows: National Security Architeture ( UK); National Security Legislation ( EUAM); Democratic/ Institutional oversight and Accountabtility ( UNDP); Critical Infrastructure Protection (UNDP-EECC Programme); Criminal Justice and Law Enforcement ( UNDP); Intelligence Community ( Germany); and Defence and Internal Security Strategy (US).
Work continues on the further development of the SSRP implementation plan which aligns SSR Priorities, Timelines and Resources, noting that a review of the overarching National Security Strategy (NSS) will be undertaken by UNDP on the request of ONSA to ensure its alignment with the Draft new government programme that was promulgated by the new Prime Minister in November 2018. Iinitial work suggests that the original NSS has ‘stood up to time’ well. It is likely (but not confirmed) that priorities are changed to show ‘Corruption’ ahead of ‘Terrorism’ in the post - conflict context with potentially ‘Water Resources’ added as an additional priority. No changes are expected in the ‘Organized Crime’ priority. Similarly it is expected that NSS will require to empahsis the new goernments priority on security transition from ISF to Local Police in post conflict Iraq. UNDP has formally offered to support this work following request from ONSA and this work is expected to start shortly.
All system priorities are operational including with an international partner ( IP) assiged to each system priority to lead the IP coordination. The SSRP support committee benefied from a series of workshops and orientations facilitied by UNDP based on their priority skill buidling needs in the areas of monitoring and evaluation and measruing progress of the SSRP implementation, Democratic Oversight and maximising civil society engagement in GoI SSR efforts as well in specific technical topics corresponding to the SSRP 7 System priorities such as Security Architecture. SSR Support Committee meets regularly and delivered the task of SSRP implementation including its semi annual and annaul progress reporting to the High Committee with advice and assistance from UNDP where needed.
Under Criminal Justice and Law Enforcment priority ( UNDP Lead) - With advice and assistance from UNDP MoI successfully developed the Local Police Service Road Map that focuses on its transition from Green ( a millitarized force) to Blue service oriented policing. The Road Map was endorsed by the MoI Minister on 16 May 2018, the impleentation plan was approved by him on 21 August 2018 and the Road Map was launched by the Deputy Minister Police Affairs Agency MoI on 12 November 2018. MoI appointed Road Map Committe and the newly appointed Central Committee composing senior officials representing Police Affairs Agency and relevant Directorates and Agencies as well with Provincial level committees headed by Provincial Police Commands will be resonpsible for its implemenation with advice and assistance from UNDP. A series of workshops started from 24 - 29 November 2018 to orient both relevant MoI senior and mid level officials and provincial level police commands on the Road Map as the first step to initiating its implementation phase. A total of 80 senior and mid ranking officials attended from MoI and the 15 provinces in Iraq.
The Road Map also recognizes the importance of having skilled and confident police officers who are able to carry forward these reforms both at national and local levels. Training and mentoring of Iraqi police therefore takes precedence both as a priority task and as an actionable recommendation. Therefore in parallel, UNDP is also assisting with the following training priorities on the request of MoI.
• Improving Effectiveness of Police (IELP) : focuses on up skilling Iraqi police to implement the Local Police Road Map at national and local levels with emphasis on crime management. Includes basic training and mentoring to mid ranking officials operational on the ground and TOT courses to police trainers with a view to hand over the training to Iraqi police in time. A Total of 6 basic and TOT courses were completed and 96 mid ranking officers from liberated and other areas benefied from the trainings. Trainings were followed by 4 mentoring sessions. Following the first IELP basic and ToT trainings a course review workshop was also held in May 2018 to further refine the course material in collaboration with MoI.
• Mid-Level Police Leadership and Management: focuses up skilling Police Mid-Level Leadership to lead the reform priorities and transform policy into tangible change in the operational environment by equipping them with modern managerial techniques and, skills in order to guide themselves and their peers in performing police duties in-line with organizational code of conduct and national/international standards. The first course was held from 11-29 November 2018 and a total of 28 mid ranking police managers from liberated and other areas benefitied from the course. From 2-6 December a course review workshop was helpd to further refine the course material following feedbackk from the participants. Rest of the courses will resume from January 2019. Overall the Police courses were well received by the participatns and the MoI and the courses were designed and delivered through a collaborative partnership between UNDP, MoI and Danish National Police.
During the reporting period UNDP also provided advice and assistance to GoI Criminal Justice Working Group composing MoI, HJC and MoJ to develop SoPs on the identifed CJ reform Criminla Invesitigations. Final interation of the SoP in Criminal Investigations within the identified CJ reform priorities with broader SSRP implementation is compled and seeking final endorsement from CJWG to submit for MoI endorsement. Tracker survey to guage peoples perception on satey and security in Iraq started in November and the field work is expected to be completed by 31 December 2018.
In Feburary 2018 within UNDP support to Democratic/ Instutional Oversight and Accountability system priority - the by laws on oversight for the Security nd Defence Committee (SDC) was endorsed by the parliament. SDC worked with UNDP advice and assistance to develop the by laws which was identified as pressing gap and a need for them to play an active role in oversight of SSR in Iraq. While advce and assitance to SDC and civil society to conduct public hearings was another key target for 2018 under this system priority this activity had be postponed due to the prologned formation of the new government following parliamentary elections in May 2018. However in order to ensure that the civil society engagement continues UNDP undertook a tracker surevey on public perceptions on safety and security across 6 provinces in Iraq ( Baghdad, Basra, Nineva, Anbar, Karbala, Sala- Al- Din). The field survey is expected to complete by 31 December 2018 with the report scheduled for January 2019.
Additionally UNDP also provided project grants to durng the reporting period to 9 selected civil society organsiations (CSOs) to implement quick impact projectsOverall objective of the quick impact projects is to build/improve public - state security and justice sector trusted partnerships at local level and the target locations include a combination of liberated and other areas i.e. Baghdad, Karbala, Anbar, Salah- Al- Din and Ninawa.
